encodingDesc.p: The characters are identified by idREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Henry V Ned Tom Jockey First Receiver Second Receiver Robin Dericke John Thief Boy Lawyer Cobbler Lord Oxford Mayor King Henry IV Judge Jailor Porter Archbishop Justice Captain Wife Two or more characters simultaneously French King Dolphin Messenger Secretary Katherine York Lord Exeter First Soldier Second Soldier Drummer Herald English Soldier Clerk Sir John Oldcastle Lord High Constable of France Third Soldier French man Glansdale Sergeant Sentinal Soldier Captain Porter Lawyer Keeper All Watch Basset Servant bearing John Talbot Messenger 3 Officer reading proclamation Duke of Burgundy

body.head: The Famous Victories of Henry the fifth, Containing the Honourable Battle of Agin-court:
body.stage: Enter the yoong Prince, Ned, and Tom.

sp.speaker: Henry the fifth.
sp.l: Come away Ned and Tom.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Henr. 5.
sp.l: Come away my Lads:
Tell me sirs, how much gold have you got?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, I have got five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But tell me Tom, how much hast thou got?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, some four hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Four hundred pounds, bravely spoken Lads.
sp.p: But tell me sirs, think you not that it was a villainous part of me to rob my fathers Receivers?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Why no my Lord, it was but a trick of youth.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Faith Ned thou sayst true.
But tell me sirs, whereabouts are we?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: My Lord, we are now about a mile off London.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But sirs, I marvel that sir Iohn Old-castle
Comes not away: Sounds see where he comes.
How now Iockey, what news with thee?

sp.speaker: Iockey.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, such news as passeth,
For the Town of Detfort is risen,
With hue and cry after your man,
Which parted from us the last night,
And has set upon, and hath robbed a poor Carrier.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: 'Swounds, the villain that was wont to spy
Out our booties.

sp.speaker: Iock.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, even the very same.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now base minded rascal to rob a poor carrier,
Well it skills not, I will save the base villains life:
Aye, I may: but tell me Iockey, whereabout be the Receivers?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, they are hard by,
But the best is, we are a-horseback and they be a-foot,
So we may escape them.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well, aye the villains come, let me alone with them.
But tell me Iockey, how much gots thou from the knaves?
For I am sure I got something, for one of the villains
So belammed me about the shoulders,
As I shall feel it this month.

sp.speaker: Iock.
sp.l: Faith my Lord, I have got a hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: A hundred pound, now bravely spoken Iockey:
But come sirs, lay all your money before me,
Now by heaven here is a brave show:
But as I am true Gentleman, I will have the half
Of this spent tonight, but sirs take up your bags,
Here comes the Receivers, let me alone.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Alas good fellow, what shall we do?
I dare never go home to the Court, for I shall be hanged.
But look, here is the young Prince, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: How now you villains, what are you?

sp.speaker: One Recei.
sp.l: Speak you to him.

sp.speaker: Other.
sp.l: No I pray, speak you to him.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why how now you rascals, why speak you not?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Forsooth we be. Pray speak you to him.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: 'Swounds, villains speak, or I will cut off your heads.

sp.speaker: Other.
sp.l: Forsooth he can tell the tale better than I.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Forsooth we be your fathers Receivers.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Are you my fathers Receivers?
Then I hope ye have brought me some money.

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Money, Alas sir we be robbed.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Robbed, how many were there of them?

sp.speaker: One.
sp.l: Marry sir, there were four of them:
And one of them had sir Iohn Old-Castles bay Hobby,
And your black Nag.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: God's wounds how like you this Iockey?
Blood you villains: my father robbed of his money abroad,
And we robbed in our stables.
But tell me, how many were of them?

sp.speaker: One recei.
sp.l: If it please you, there were four of them,
And there was one about the bigness of you:
But I am sure I so belammed him about the shoulders,
That he will feel it this month.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: God's wounds you lamed them fairly,
So that they have carried away your money.
But come sirs, what shall we do with the villains?

sp.speaker: Both recei.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, be good to us.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: I pray you my Lord forgive them this once.
Well stand up and get you gone,
And look that you speak not a word of it,
For if there be, 'Swounds I will hang you and all your kin.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now sirs, how like you this?
Was not this bravely done?
For now the villains dare not speak a word of it,
I have so feared them with words.
Now whither shall we go?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Why my Lord, you know our old hostess
At Feuersham.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Our hostess at Feuersham, blood what shall we do there?
We have a thousand pound about us,
And we shall go to a petty alehouse.
No, no: you know the old Tavern in Eastcheape,
There is good wine: besides, there is a pretty wench
That can talk well, for I delight as much in their tongues,
As any part about them.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We are ready to wait upon your grace.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: God's wounds wait, we will go altogether,
We are all fellows, I tell you sirs, if the King
My father were dead, we would be all Kings,
Therefore come away.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: God's wounds, bravely spoken Harry.

body.stage: Enter Iohn Cobler, Robin Pewterer, Lawrence Costermonger.

sp.speaker: Iohn Cob.
sp.l: All is well here, all is well masters.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: How say you neighbour Iohn Cobbler?
I think it best that my neighbour
Robin Pewterer went to Pudding lane end,
And we will watch here at Billinsgate ward.
How say you neighbour Robin, how like you this?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Marry well neighbours:
I care not much if I go to Pudding lanes end.
But neighbours, if you hear any ado about me,
Make haste: and if I hear any ado about you,
I will come to you.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Neighbour, what news hear you of the young Prince:

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Marry neighbour, I hear say, he is a toward young Prince,
For if he met any by the hie way,
He will not let to talk with him,
I dare not call him thief, but sure he is one of these taking fellows.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Indeed neighbour I hear say he is as lively
A young Prince as ever was.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye, and I hear say, if he use it long,
His father will cut him off from the Crown:
But neighbour say nothing of that.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: No, no, neighbour, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Neighbour, methinks you begin to sleep,
If you will, we will sit down,
For I think it is about midnight.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: Marry content neighbour, let us sleep.

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: Who, who there, who there?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: O neighbours, what mean you to sleep,
And such ado in the streets?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: How now neighbour, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: Who there, who there, who there?

sp.speaker: Cobler.
sp.l: Why what ailest thou? here is no horses.

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: O alas man, I am robbed, who there, who there?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Hold him neighbour Cobbler.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Why I see thou art a plain Clown.

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: Am I a Clown, 'Swounds masters,
Do Clowns go in silk apparel?
I am sure all we gentlemen Clowns in Kent scant go so
Well: 'Swounds you know clowns very well:
Hear you, are you master Constable, and you bespeak?
For I will not take it at his hands.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Faith I am not master Constable,
But I am one of his bad officers, for he is not here.

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: Is not master Constable here?
Well it is no matter, I will have the law at his hands.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Nay I pray you do not take the law of us.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Well, you are one of his beastly officers.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I am one of his bad officers.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why then I charge thee look to him.

sp.speaker: Cobler.
sp.l: Nay but hear ye sir, you seem to be an honest
Fellow, and we are poor men, and now it is night:
And we would be loath to have anything ado,
Therefore I pray thee put it up.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: First, thou sayst true, I am an honest fellow,
And a proper handsome fellow too,
And you seem to be poor men, therefore I care not greatly,
Nay, I am quickly pacified:
But if you chance to spy the thief,
I pray you lay hold on him.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Yes that we will, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: It is a wonderful thing to see how glad the knave
Is, now I have forgiven him.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Neighbours do ye look about you?
How now, who is there?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Here is a good fellow, I pray you which is the
Way to the old Tavern in Eastcheape?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Whoop holla, now Gads Hill, knowest thou me?

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: I know thee for an Ass.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: And I know thee for a taking fellow,
Upon Gads hill in Kent:
A bots light upon ye.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: The whoreson villain would be knocked.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Masters, villain, if ye be men stand to him,
And take his weapon from him, let him not pass you.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: My friend, what make you abroad now?
It is too late to walk now.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: It is not too late for true men to walk.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.l: We know thee not to be a true man.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: Why what do you mean to do with me?
'Swounds I am one of the kings liege people.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Hear you sir, are you one of the kings liege people?

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: Aye marry am I sir, what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Marry sir, I say you are one of the Kings filching people.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Come, come, let us have him away.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: Why what have I done?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Thou hast robbed a poor fellow,
And taken away his goods from him.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: I never saw him before.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Masters who comes here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: How now good man Cobbler?

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: How now Robin, what makes thou abroad
At this time of night?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.l: Marry I have been at the Counter,
I can tell such news as never you have heard the like.

sp.speaker: Cobler.
sp.l: What is that Robin, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Why this night about two hours ago, there came the young Prince, and three or four more of his companions, and called for wine good store, and then they sent for a noise of Musicians, and were very merry for the space of an hour, then whether their Music liked them not, or whether they had drunk too much Wine or no, I cannot tell, but our pots flue against the walls, and then they drew their swords, and went into the street and fought, and some took one part, and some took another, but for the space of half an hour, there was such a bloody fray as passeth, and none could part them until such time as the Mayor and Sheriff were sent for, and then at the last with much ado, they took them, and so the young Prince was carried to the Counter, and then about one hour after, there came a Messenger from the Court in all haste from the King, for my Lord Mayor and the Sheriff, but for what cause I know not.

sp.speaker: Cobler.
sp.p: Here is news indeed Robert.

sp.speaker: Law.
sp.p: Marry neighbour, this news is strange indeed, I think it best neighbour, to rid our hands of this fellow first.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.p: What mean you to do with me?

sp.speaker: Cobler.
sp.p: We mean to carry you to the prison, and there to remain till the Sessions day,

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.p: Then I pray you let me go to the prison where my master is.

sp.speaker: Cob.
sp.l: Nay thou must go to the country prison, to newgate,
Therefore come away.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: I prithee be good to me honest fellow.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Aye marry will I, I will be very charitable to thee,
For I will never leave thee, till I see thee on the Gallows.

body.stage: Enter Henry the fourth, with the Earle of Exeter, and the Lord of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.p: Aye please your Majesty, here is my Lord Mayor and the Sheriff of London, to speak with your Majesty.

sp.speaker: K. Hen. 4.
sp.l: Admit them to our presence.
sp.stage: Enter the Maior and the Sheriffe.
sp.l: Now my good Lord Mayor of London,
sp.p: The cause of my sending for you at this time, is to tell you of a matter which I have learned of my Council: Herein I understand, that you have committed my son to prison without our leave and license. What although he be a rude youth, and likely to give occasion, yet you might have considered that he is a Prince, and my son, and not to be haled to prison by every subject.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: May it please your Majesty to give us leave to tell our tale?

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.p: Or else God forbid, otherwise you might think me an unequal Judge, having more affection to my son, than to any rightful judgment.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: Then I do not doubt but we shall rather deserve commendations at your Majesties hands, than any anger.

sp.speaker: K. Hen. 4.
sp.p: Go to, say on.

sp.speaker: Maior.
sp.p: Then if it please your Majesty, this night betwixt two and three of the clock in the morning, my Lord the young Prince with a very disordered company, came to the old Tavern in Eastcheape, and whether it was that their Music liked them not, or whether they were overcome with wine, I know not, but they drew their swords, and into the street they went, and some took my Lord the young Princes part, and some took the other, but betwixt them there was such a bloody fray for the space of half an hour, that neither watchmen nor any other could stay them, till my brother the Sheriff of London and I were sent for, and at the last with much ado we stayed them, but it was long first, which was a great disquieting to all your loving subjects thereabouts: and then my good Lord, we knew not whether your grace had sent them to try us, whether we would do justice, or whether it were of their own voluntary will or not, we cannot tell: and therefore in such a case we knew not what to do, but for our own safeguard we sent him to ward, where he wanteth nothing that is fit for his grace, and your Majesties son. And thus most humbly beseeching your Majesty to think of our answer.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.p: Stand aside until we have further deliberated on your answer.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Ah Harry, Harry, now thrice accursed Harry,
That hath gotten a son, which with grief
Will end his fathers days.
O my son, a Prince thou art, I a Prince indeed,
And to deserve imprisonment,
And well have they done, and like faithful subjects:
Discharge them and let them go.

sp.speaker: L. Exe.
sp.p: I beseech your Grace, be good to my Lord the young Prince.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.p: Nay, nay, it is no matter, let him alone.

sp.speaker: L. Oxf.
sp.p: Perchance the Mayor and the Sheriff have been too precise in this matter.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: No: they have done like faithful subjects:
I will go myself to discharge them, and let them go.

body.stage: Enter Lord chiefe Iustice, Clarke of the Office, Iayler, Iohn Cobler, Dericke, and the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Jailer bring the prisoner to the bar.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Hear you my Lord, I pray you bring the bar to the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Hold thy hand up at the bar.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Here it is my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Clerk of the Office, read his indictment.

sp.speaker: Cleark.
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: My name was known before I came here,
And shall be when I am gone, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Aye, I think so, but we will know it better before thou go.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: 'Swounds if you do but send to the next Jail,
We are sure to know his name,
For this is not the first prison he hath been in, I will warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clearke
sp.l: What is thy name?

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: What need you to ask, and have it in writing.

sp.speaker: Clearke
sp.l: Is not thy name Cutbert Cutter?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.p: What the Devil need you ask, and know it so well.

sp.speaker: Cleark.
sp.p: Why then Cutbert Cutter, I indict thee by the name of Cutbert Cutter, for robbing a poor carrier the twenty day of May last past, in the fourteen year of the reign of our sovereign Lord King Henry the fourth, for setting upon a poor Carrier upon Gads hill in Kent, and having beaten and wounded the said Carrier, and taken his goods from him.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: O masters stay there, nay let us never belie the man, for he hath not beaten and wounded me also, but he hath beaten and wounded my pack, and hath taken the great raze of Ginger, that bouncing Besse with the jolly buttocks should have had, that grieves me most.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Well, what sayst thou, art thou guilty, or not guilty?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.p: Not guilty, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: By whom wilt thou be tried?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.p: By my Lord the young Prince, or by myself whether you will.

body.stage: Enter the young Prince, with Ned and Tom.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Come away my lads, God's wounds ye villain, what make you here? I must go about my business myself, and you must stand loitering here.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.p: Why my Lord, they have bound me, and will not let me go.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Have they bound thee villain, why how now my Lord?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: I am glad to see your grace in good health.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why my Lord, this is my man,
It is marvel you knew him not long before this,
I tell you he is a man of his hands.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Aye God's wounds that I am, try me who dare

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Your Grace shall find small credit by acknowledging him to be your man.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why my Lord, what hath he done?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty, he hath robbed a poor Carrier.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Hear you sir, marry it was one Dericke,
Goodman Hoblings man of Kent.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: What was it you button-breech?
Of my word my Lord, he did it but in jest.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Hear you sir, is it your man's quality to rob folks in jest? I'faith, he shall be hanged in earnest.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Well my Lord, what do you mean to do with my man?

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: If please your grace, the law must pass on him,
According to justice, then he must be executed.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Hear you sir, I pray you, is it your man's quality to rob folks in jest? I'faith he shall be hanged in jest.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Well my Lord, what mean you to do with my man?

sp.speaker: Iudg.
sp.l: If please your grace the law must pass on him,
According to justice, then he must be executed.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Why then belike you mean to hang my man?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: I am sorry that it falls out so.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why my Lord, I pray ye who am I?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.p: If please your Grace, you are my Lord the young Prince, our King that shall be after the decease of our sovereign Lord, King Henry the fourth, whom God grant long to reign.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: You say true my Lord:
And you will hang my man.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: If like your grace, I must needs do justice.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Tell me my Lord, shall I have my man?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: I cannot my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But will you not let him go?

sp.speaker: Iud.
sp.l: I am sorry that his case is so ill.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Tush, case me no casings, shall I have my man?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: I cannot, nor I may not my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Nay, if I shall not say, and then I am answered?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: No: then I will have him.
He giveth him a box on the ear.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: God's wounds my Lord, shall I cut off his head?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: No, I charge you draw not your swords,
But get you hence, provide a noise of Musicians,
Away, be gone.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Well my Lord, I am content to take it at your hands.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Nay if you be not, you shall have more.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.l: Why I pray you my Lord, who am I?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: You, who knows not you?
Why man, you are Lord chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Your Grace hath said truth, therefore in striking me in this place, you greatly abuse me, and not me only, but also your father: whose lively person here in this place I do represent. And therefore to teach you what prerogatives mean, I commit you to the Fleet, until we have spoken with your father.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Why then belike you mean to send me to the Fleet?

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Aye indeed, and therefore carry him away.

sp.speaker: Iudge
sp.p: Jailer, carry the prisoner to Newgate again, until the next Sises.

sp.speaker: Iay.
sp.l: At your commandment my Lord, it shall be done.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: 'Swounds masters, here is ado,
When Princes must go to prison:
Why Iohn, didst ever see the like?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: O Dericke, trust me, I never saw the like.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why Iohn thou mayst see what princes be in choler,
A Judge a box on the ear, I will tell thee Iohn, O Iohn,
I would not have done it for twenty shillings.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No nor I, there had been no way but one with us,
We should have been hanged.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Faith Iohn, I will tell thee what, thou shalt be my
Lord chief Justice, and thou shalt sit in the chair,
And I will be the young prince, and hit thee a box on the ear,
And then thou shalt say, to teach you what prerogatives
Mean, I commit you to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Come on, I will be your Judge,
But thou shalt not hit me hard.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: No, no.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What hath he done?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Marry he hath robbed Dericke.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why then I cannot let him go.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I must needs have my man.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: You shall not have him.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Shall I not have my man, say no if you dare:
How say you, shall I not have my man?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No marry shall you not.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Shall I not Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No Dericke.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why then take you that till more come,
'Swounds, shall I not have him?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Well I am content to take this at your hand,
But I pray you, who am I?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Who art thou, 'Swounds, dost not know thyself?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Now away simple fellow,
Why man, thou art Iohn the Cobbler.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: No, I am my Lord chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O Iohn, Mass thou sayst true, thou art indeed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: Why then to teach you what prerogatives mean I commit you to the Fleet.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Well I will go, but i'faith you gray beard knave,
sp.p: I will course you. O Iohn, Come, come out of thy chair, why what a clown wert thou, to let me hit thee a box on the ear, and now thou seest they will not take me to the Fleet, I think that thou art one of these Worenday Clowns.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But I marvel what will become of thee?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Faith I will be no more a Carrier.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What wilt thou do then?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I will dwell with thee and be a Cobbler.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: With me, alas I am not able to keep thee,
Why thou wilt eat me out of doors.

sp.speaker: Der
sp.p: O Iohn, no Iohn, I am none of these great slouching fellows, that devour these great pieces of beef and brews, alas a trifle serves me, a Woodcock, a Chicken, or a Capons leg, or any such little thing serves me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: a Capon, why man, I cannot get a Capon once a year, except it be at Christmas, at some other man's house, for we Cobblers be glad of a dish of roots.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Roots, why are you so good at rooting?
Nay Cobbler, we will have you ringed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But Dericke, though we be so poor,
Yet will we have in store a crab in the fire,
With nut-brown Ale, that is full stale,
Which will a man quail, and lay in the mire.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: A bots on you, and be but for your Ale,
I will dwell with you, come let us away as fast as we can.

body.stage: Enter the yoong Prince, with Ned and Tom.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come away sirs, God's wounds Ned,
Didst thou not see what a box on the ear
I took my Lord chief Justice?

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: By god's blood it did me good to see it,
It made his teeth jar in his head.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: How now sir Iohn Old-Castle,
What news with you?

sp.speaker: Ioh. Old.
sp.l: I am glad to see your grace at liberty,
I was come I, to visit you in prison.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: To visit me, didst thou not know that I am a Princes son, why it is enough for me to look into a prison, though I come not in myself, but here is such ado nowadays, here is prisoning, here is hanging, whipping, and the devil and all: but I tell you sirs, when I am King, we will have no such things, but my lads, if the old king my father were dead, we would be all kings.

sp.speaker: Ioh. Old.
sp.p: He is a good old man, God take him to his mercy the sooner.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But Ned, so soon as I am King, the first thing
I will do, shall be to put my Lord chief Justice out of office,
And thou shalt be my Lord chief Justice of England.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Shall I be Lord chief Justice?
By god's wounds, I will be the bravest Lord chief Justice
That ever was in England.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Then Ned, I will turn all these prisons into fence Schools, and I will endue thee with them, with lands to maintain them withal: then I will have about with my Lord chief Justice, thou shalt hang none but pick purses and horse stealers, and such base minded villains, but that fellow that will stand by the high way side courageously with his sword and buckler and take a purse, that fellow give him commendations, beside that, send him to me and I will give him an annual pension out of my Exchequer, to maintain him all the days of his life.

sp.speaker: Ioh.
sp.p: Nobly spoken Harry, we shall never have a merry world till the old king be dead.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: But whither are ye going now?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: To the Court, for I hear say, my father lies very sick.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: But I doubt he will not die.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Yet will I go thither, for the breath shall be no sooner out of his mouth, but I will clap the Crown on my head.

sp.speaker: Iockey.
sp.p: Will you go to the Court with that cloak so full of needles?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Cloak, eyelet-holes, needles, and all was of mine own devising, and therefore I will wear it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.p: I pray you my Lord, what may be the meaning thereof?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Why man, it is a sign that I stand upon thorns, till the Crown be on my head.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.p: Or that every needle might be a prick to their hearts that repine at your doings.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Thou sayst true Iockey, but there is some will say, the young Prince will be a well toward young man and all this gear, that I had as leave they would break my head with a pot, as to say any such thing, but we stand prating here too long, I must needs speak with my father, therefore come away.

sp.speaker: Porter.
sp.p: What a rapping keep you at the Kings Court gate?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Here is one that must speak with the King.

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: The King is very sick, and none must speak with him.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: No you rascal, do you not know me?

sp.speaker: Por.
sp.p: You are my Lord the young Prince.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Then go and tell my father, that I must and will speak with him.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: Shall I cut off his head?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: No, no, though I would help you in other places, yet I have nothing to do here, what you are in my fathers Court.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.p: I will write him in my Tables, for so soon as I am made Lord chief Justice, I will put him out of his Office.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: God's wounds sirs, the King comes,
Let us all stand aside.

body.stage: Enter the King, with the Lord of Exeter.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.p: And is it true my Lord, that my son is already sent to the Fleet? now truly that man is more fitter to rule the Realm than I, for by no means could I rule my son, and he by one word hath caused him to be ruled. O my son, my son, no sooner out of one prison, but into another, I had thought once whiles I had lived, to have seen this noble Realm of England flourish by thee my son, but now I see it goes to ruin and decay.

sp.speaker: Ox.
sp.l: If please your grace, here is my Lord your son,
That cometh to speak with you,
He saith, he must and will speak with you.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Who my son Harry?

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Aye if please your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: I know wherefore he cometh,
But look that none come with him.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: A very disordered company, and such as make
Very ill rule in your Majesties house.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Well let him come,
But look that none come with him.
He goeth.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: If please your grace,
My Lord the King, sends for you.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come away sirs, let us go all together.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: If please your grace, none must go with you.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why I must needs have them with me,
Otherwise I can do my father no countenance,
Therefore come away.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: The King your father commands
There should none come.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well sirs then be gone,
And provide me three Noise of Musicians.

body.stage: Enters the Prince with a dagger in his hand.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Come my son, come on a-Gods name,
I know wherefore thy coming is,
O my son, my son, what cause hath ever been,
That thou shouldest forsake me, and follow this vild and
Reprobate company, which abuseth youth so manifestly:
O my son, thou knowest that these thy doings
Will end thy fathers days.
sp.p: Aye so, so, my son, thou fearest not to approach the presence of thy sick father, in that disguised sort, I tell thee my son, that there is never a needle in thy cloak, but it is a prick to my heart, and never an eyelet-hole, but it is a hole to my soul: and wherefore thou bringest that dagger in thy hand I know not, but by conjecture.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: My conscience accuseth me, most sovereign Lord, and well-beloved father, to answer first to the last point, That is, whereas you conjecture that this hand and this dagger shall be armed against your life: no, know my beloved father, far be the thoughts of your son, son said I, an unworthy son for so good a father: but far be the thoughts of any such pretended mischief: and I most humbly render it to your Majesties hand, and live my Lord and sovereign forever: and with your dagger arm show like vengeance upon the body of that your son, I was about say and dare not, ah woe is me therefore, that your wild slave, it is not the Crown that I come for, sweet father, because I am unworthy, and those vild and reprobate company I abandon, and utterly abolish their company forever. Pardon sweet father, pardon: the least thing and most desire: and this ruffianly cloak, I here tear from my back, and sacrifice it to the devil, which is master of all mischief: Pardon me, sweet father, pardon me: good my Lord of Exeter speak for me: pardon me, pardon good father, not a word: ah he will not speak one word: A Harry, now thrice unhappy Harry. But what shall I do? I will go take me into some solitary place, and there lament my sinful life, and when I have done, I will lay me down and die.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Call him again, call my son again.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: And doth my father call me again? now Harry,
Happy be the time that thy father calleth thee again.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Stand up my son, and do not think thy father,
But at the request of thee my son, I will pardon thee,
And God bless thee, and make thee his servant.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Thanks good my Lord, and no doubt but this day,
Even this day, I am borne new again.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Come my son and Lords, take me by the hands.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Thou art a stinking whore, and a whoreson stinking whore,
Dost think I will take it at thy hands?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Derick, D. D. Hearesta,
Do D. never while thou livest use that,
Why what will my neighbours say, if thou go away so?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: She is an arrant whore, and I will have the law on you Iohn.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why what hath she done?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Marry mark thou Iohn.
I will prove it that I will.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What wilt thou prove?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: That she called me in to dinner.
Iohn, mark the tale well Iohn, and when I was set,
She brought me a dish of roots, and a piece of barrel butter
therein: and she is a very knave,
And thou a drab if thou take her part.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Hearesta Dericke, is this the matter?
Nay, if it be no worse, we will go home again,
And all shall be amended.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O Iohn, hearesta Iohn, is all well?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye, all is well.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.p: Then I will go home before, and break all the glass windows.

body.stage: Enter the King with his Lords.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.p: Come my Lords, I see it boots me not to take any physic, for all the Physicians in the world cannot cure me, no not one. But good my Lords, remember my last will and Testament concerning my son, for truly my Lords, I do not think but he will prove as valiant and victorious a King, as ever reigned in England.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Let heaven and earth be witness between us, if we accomplish not thy will to the uttermost.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: I give you most unfeigned thanks, good my lords,
Draw the Curtains and depart my chamber a while,
And cause some Music to rock me asleep.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.p: Ah Harry, thrice unhappy, that hath neglect so long from visiting of thy sick father, I will go, nay but why do I not go to the Chamber of my sick father, to comfort the melancholy soul of his body, his soul said I, here is his body indeed, but his soul is, whereas it needs no body. Now thrice accursed Harry, that hath offended thy father so much, and could not I crave pardon for all. O my dying father, cursed be the day wherein I was borne, and accursed be the hour wherein I was begotten, but what shall I do? if weeping tears which come too late, may suffice the negligence neglected to some, I will weep day and night until the fountain be dry with weeping.

body.stage: Enter Lord of Exeter and Oxford.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: Come easily my Lord, for waking of the King.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Now my Lords.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: How doth your Grace feel your self?

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Somewhat better after my sleep,
But good my Lords take off my Crown,
Remove my chair a little back, and set me right.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.l: If please your grace, the crown is taken away.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: The Crown taken away,
Good my Lord of Oxford, go see who hath done this deed:
No doubt it is some vild traitor that hath done it,
To deprive my son, they that would do it now,
Would seek to scrape and scrawl for it after my death.

body.stage: Enter Lord of Oxford with the Prince.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: Here if please your Grace,
Is my Lord the young Prince with the Crown.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Why how now my son?
I had thought the last time I had you in schooling,
I had given you a lesson for all,
And do you now begin again?
Why tell me my son,
Dost thou think the time so long,
That thou wouldst have it before the
Breath be out of my mouth?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Most sovereign Lord, and well-beloved father,
I came into your Chamber to comfort the melancholy
Soul of your body, and finding you at that time
Past all recovery, and dead to my thinking,
God is my witness: and what should I do,
But with weeping tears lament the death of you my father,
And after that, seeing the Crown, I took it:
And tell me my father, who might better take it than I,
After your death? but seeing you live,
I most humbly render it into your Majesties hands,
And the happiest man alive, that my father live:
And live my Lord and Father, forever.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Stand up my son,
Thine answer hath sounded well in mine ears,
For I must need confess that I was in a very sound sleep,
And altogether unmindful of thy coming:
But come near my son,
And let me put thee in possession whilst I live,
That none deprive thee of it after my death.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well may I take it at your majesties hands,
But it shall never touch my head, so long as my father lives.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: God give thee joy my son,
God bless thee and make thee his servant,
And send thee a prosperous reign.
For God knows my son, how hardly I came by it,
And how hardly I have maintained it.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Howsoever you came by it, I know not,
But now I have it from you, and from you I will keep it:
And he that seeks to take the Crown from my head,
Let him look that his armour be thicker than mine,
Or I will pearce him to the heart,
Were it harder than brass or bullion.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: Nobly spoken, and like a King.
Now trust me my Lords, I fear not but my son
Will be as warlike and victorious a Prince,
As ever reigned in England.

sp.speaker: L. Ambo.
sp.l: His former life shows no less.

sp.speaker: Hen. 4.
sp.l: well my lords, I know not whether it be for sleep,
Or drawing near of drowsy summer of death,
But I am very much given to sleep,
Therefore good my Lords and my son,
Draw the Curtains, depart my Chamber,
And cause some Music to rock me asleep.

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Ah God, I am now much like to a Bird
Which hath escaped out of the Cage,
For so soon as my Lord chief justice heard
That the old King was dead, he was glad to let me go,
For fear of my Lord the young Prince:
But here comes some of his companions,
I will see if I can get anything of them,
For old acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: God's wounds, the King is dead.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Dead, then god's blood, we shall be all kings.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: God's wounds, I shall be Lord chief Justice
Of England.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: Why how, are you broken out of prison?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: God's wounds, how the villain stinks.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Why what will become of thee now?
Fie upon him, how the rascal stinks.

sp.speaker: Theef.
sp.l: Marry I will go and serve my master again.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: God's blood, dost think that he will have any such
Scabbed knave as thou art? what man he is a king now.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: Hold thee, here is a couple of Angels for thee,
And get thee gone, for the King will not be long
Before he come this way:
And hereafter I will tell the king of thee.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: O how it did me good, to see the king
When he was crowned:
Me thought his seat was like the figure of heaven,
And his person like unto a God.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: But who would have thought,
That the king would have changed his countenance so?

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: Did you not see with what grace
He sent his embassage into France? to tell the French king
That Harry of England hath sent for the Crown,
And Harry of England will have it.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: But it was but a little to make the people believe,
That he was sorry for his fathers death.

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: God's wounds, the king comes,
Let us all stand aside.

body.stage: Enter the King with the Archbishop, and the Lord of Oxford.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: How do you my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ned.
sp.l: How now Harry?
Tut my Lord, put away these dumps,
You are a king, and all the realm is yours:
What man, do you not remember the old sayings,
You know I must be Lord chief Justice of England,
Trust me my lord, methinks you are very much changed,
And it is but with a little sorrowing, to make folks believe
The death of your father grieves you,
And it is nothing so.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: I prithee Ned, mend thy manners,
And be more modester in thy terms,
For my unfeigned grief is not to be ruled by thy flattering
And dissembling talk, thou sayst I am changed,
So I am indeed, and so must thou be, and that quickly,
Or else I must cause thee to be changed.

sp.speaker: Ioc.
sp.l: God's wounds how like you this?
'Swounds it is not so sweet as Music.

sp.speaker: Tom.
sp.l: I trust we have not offended your grace no way.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Ah Tom, your former life grieves me,
And makes me to abandon and abolish your company forever
And therefore not upon pain of death to approach my presence
By ten miles space, then if I hear well of you,
It may be I will do somewhat for you,
Otherwise look for no more favour at my hands,
Than at any other man's: And therefore be gone,
We have other matters to talk on.
Now my good Lord Archbishop of Canterbury,
What say you to our Embassage into France?

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Your right to the French Crown of France,
Came by your great grandmother Izabel,
Wife to King Edward the third,
And sister to Charles the French King:
Now if the French king deny it, as likely enough he will,
Then must you take your sword in hand,
And conquer the right.
Let the usurped Frenchman know,
Although your predecessors have let it pass, you will not:
For your Country men are willing with purse and men,
To aide you.
Then my good Lord, as it hath been always known,
That Scotland hath been in league with France,
By a sort of pensions which yearly come from thence,
I think it therefore best to conquer Scotland,
And the I think that you may go more easily into France:
And this is all that I can say, My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: I thank you, my good lord Archbishop of Canterbury.
What say you my good Lord of Oxford?

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: And If please your Majesty,
I agree to my Lord Archbishop, saving in this,
He that will Scotland win, must first with France begin:
According to the old saying.
Therefore my good Lord, I think it best first to invade France,
For in conquering Scotland, you conquer but one,
And conquer France, and conquer both.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: If please your Majesty,
My Lord Ambassador is come out of France.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now trust me my Lord,
He was the last man that we talked of,
I am glad that he is come to resolve us of our answer,
Commit him to our presence.

sp.speaker: York.
sp.l: God save the life of my sovereign Lord the king,

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now my good Lord the Duke of Yorke,
What news from our brother the French King?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: If please your Majesty,
I delivered him my Embassage,
Whereof I took some deliberation,
But for the answer he hath sent,
My Lord Ambassador of Burges, the Duke of Burgony,
Monsieur le Cole, with two hundred and fifty horsemen,
To bring the Embassage.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Commit my Lord Archbishop of Burges
Into our presence.
Now my Lord Archbishop of Burges,
We do learn by our Lord Ambassador,
That you have our message to do
From our brother the French King:
Here my good Lord, according to our accustomed order,
We give you free liberty and license to speak,
With good audience.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: God save the mighty King of England,
My Lord and master, the most Christian king,
Charles the seventh, the great and mighty king of France,
As a most noble and Christian king,
Not minding to shed innocent blood, is rather content
To yield somewhat to your unreasonable demands,
That if fifty thousand crowns a year with his daughter
The said Lady Katheren, in marriage,
And some crowns which he may well spare,
Not hurting of his kingdom,
He is content to yield so far to your unreasonable desire.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why then belike your Lord and master,
Thinks to puff me up with fifty thousand crowns a year,
No tell thy Lord and master,
That all the crowns in France shall not serve me,
Except the Crown and kingdom itself:
And perchance hereafter I will have his daughter.

body.stage: He deliuereth a Tunne of Tennis balles.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
My Lord Prince Dolphin greets you well,
With this present.

body.stage: He deliuereth a Tunne of Tennis Balles.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: What a gilded Tun?
I pray you my Lord of Yorke, look what is in it?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: If it please your Grace,
Here is a Carpet and a Tun of Tennis balls.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: A Tun of Tennis balls?
I pray you good my Lord Archbishop,
What might the meaning thereof be?

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: If it please you my Lord,
A messenger you know, ought to keep close his message,
And specially an Ambassador.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But I know that you may declare your message
To a king, the law of Arms allows no less.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: My Lord hearing of your wildness before your
Fathers death, sent you this my good Lord,
Meaning that you are more fitter for a Tennis Court
Than a field, and more fitter for a Carpet than the Camp.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: My lord prince Dolphin is very pleasant with me:
But tell him, that instead of balls of leather,
We will toss him balls of brass and iron,
Yea such balls as never were tossed in France,
The proudest Tennis Court shall rue it.
Aye and thou Prince of Burges shall rue it.
Therefore get thee hence, and tell him thy message quickly,
Lest I be there before thee: Away priest, be gone.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, to deliver me your safe
Conduct under your broad seal Emanuel.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Priest of Burges, know,
That the hand and seal of a King, and his word is all one,
And instead of my hand and seal,
I will bring him my hand and sword:
And tell thy lord and master, that I Harry of England said it,
And I Harry of England, will perform it.
My Lord of Yorke, deliver him our safe conduct,
Under our broad seal Emanuel.
sp.stage: Exeunt Archbishop, and the Duke of Yorke.
sp.l: Now my Lords, to Arms, to Arms,
For I vow by heaven and earth, that the proudest
French man in all France, shall rue the time that ever
These Tennis balls were sent into England.
My Lord, I will that there be provided a great Navy of ships,
With all speed, at South-Hampton,
For there I mean to ship my men,
For I would be there before him, it it were possible,
Therefore come, but stay,
I had almost forgot the chiefest thing of all, with chafing
With this French Ambassador.
Call in my Lord chief Justice of England.

body.stage: Enters Lord chiefe Iustice of England.

sp.speaker: Exe.
sp.l: Here is the King my Lord.

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: God preserve your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why how now my lord, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Iustice.
sp.l: I would it were unknown to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why what ail you?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Your Majesty knoweth my grief well.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: O my Lord, you remember you sent me to the
Fleet, did you not?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: I trust your grace have forgotten that.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Aye truly my Lord, and for revengement,
I have chosen you to be my Protector over my Realm,
Until it shall please God to give me speedy return
Out of France.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: And if it please your Majesty, I am far unworthy
Of so high a dignity.

sp.speaker: Hen 5.
sp.l: Tut my Lord, you are not unworthy,
Because I think you worthy:
For you that would not spare me,
I think will not spare another,
It must needs be so, and therefore come,
Let us be gone, and get our men in a readiness.

body.stage: Enter a Captaine, Iohn Cobler and his wife.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Come, come, there is no remedy,
Thou must needs serve the King.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Good master Captain let me go,
I am not able to go so far.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I pray you good master Captain,
Be good to my husband.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why I am sure he is not too good to serve ye king?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Alas no: but a great deal too bad,
Therefore I pray you let me go.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: No, no, thou shalt go.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.p: O sir, I have a great many shoes at home to Cobble.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I pray you let him go home again.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Tush I care not, thou shalt go.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: O wife, if you had been a loving wife to me,
This had not been, for I have said many times,
That I would go away, and now I must go
Against my will.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: How now ho, Basillus Manus, for an old codpiece,
Master Captain shall we away?
'Swounds how now Iohn, what acrying?
What make you and my dame there?
I marvel whose head you will throw the stools at,
Now we are gone.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: I will tell you, come ye cloghead,
What do you with my pot lid? hear you,
Will you have it rapt about your pate?

body.stage: She beateth him with her potlid.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O good dame,
If I had my dagger here, I would wore you all to pieces
That I would.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Would you so, I will try that.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Master Captain will ye suffer her?
Go to dame, I will go back as far as I can,
But if you come again,
I will clap the law on your back that is flat:
I will tell you master Captain what you shall do?
Press her for a soldier, I warrant you,
She will do as much good as her husband and I too.
'Swounds, who comes yonder?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now good fellow, dost thou want a master?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Aye truly sir.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Hold thee then, I press thee for a soldier,
To serve the King in France.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: How now Gads, what dost know us thinkest?

sp.speaker: Theefe.
sp.l: Aye, I knew thee long ago.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Hear you master Captain?

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: What sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I pray you let me go home again.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: Why what wouldst thou do at home?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Marry I have brought two shirts with me,
And I would carry one of them home again,
For I am sure he will steal it from me,
He is such a filching fellow.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I warrant thee he will not steal it from thee,
Come let us away.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Come master Captain let us away,
Come follow me.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Come wife, let us part lovingly.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.l: Farewell good husband.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Fie what a kissing and crying is here?
'Swounds, do ye think he will never come again?
Why Iohn come away, dost think that we are so base
Minded to die among French men?
'Swounds, we know not whether they will lay
Us in their Church or no: Come Master. Captain, let us away.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I cannot stay no longer, therefore come away.

body.stage: Enter the King, Prince Dolphin, and Lord high Constable of France.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: Now my Lord high Constable,
What say you to our Embassage into England?

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty, I can say nothing,
Until my Lords Ambassadors be come home,
But yet methinks your grace hath done well,
To get your men in so good a readiness,
For fear of the worst.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: Aye my Lord we have some in a readiness,
But if the King of England make against us,
We must have thrice so many more.

sp.speaker: Dolphin.
sp.l: Tut my Lord, although the King of England
Be young and wild headed, yet never think he will be so
sp.p: Unwise to make battle against the mighty King of France.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: O my son, although the King of England be
Young and wild headed, yet never think but he is ruled
By his wise Councillors.

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: God save the life of my sovereign lord the king.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: Now my good Lord Archbishop of Burges,
What news from our brother the English King?

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: If please your Majesty,
He is so far from your expectation,
That nothing will serve him but the Crown
And kingdom itself, besides, he bad me haste quickly,
Lest he be there before me, and so far as I hear,
He hath kept promise, for they say, he is already landed
At Kidcocks in Normandie, upon the River of Sene,
And laid his siege to the Garrison Town of Harflew.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: You have made great haste in the mean time,
Have you not?

sp.speaker: Dolphin.
sp.l: I pray you my Lord, how did the King of
England take my presents?

sp.speaker: Archb.
sp.l: Truly my Lord, in very ill part,
For these your balls of leather,
He will toss you balls of brass and iron:
Trust me my Lord, I was very afraid of him,
He is such a haughty and high minded Prince,
He is as fierce as a Lion.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.l: Tush, we will make him as tame as a Lamb,
I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: God save the mighty King of France.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: Now Messenger, what news?

sp.speaker: Messen.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
I come from your poor distressed Town of Harflew,
Which is so beset on every side,
If your Majesty do not send present aide,
The Town will be yielded to the English King.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: Come my Lords, come, shall we stand still
Till our Country be spoiled under our noses?
My Lords, let the Normanes, Brabants, Pickardies,
And Danes, be sent for with all speed:
And you my Lord high Constable, I make General
Over all my whole Army.
Monsieur le Colle, Master of the Boas,
Seignior Deuens, and all the rest, at your appointment.

sp.speaker: Dolp.
sp.l: I trust your Majesty will bestow,
Some part of the battle on me,
I hope not to present any otherwise than well.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: I tell thee my son,
Although I should get the victory, and thou lose thy life,
I should think myself quite conquered,
And the English men to have the victory.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.l: Why my Lord and father,
I would have the petty king of England to know,
That I dare encounter him in any ground of the world.

sp.speaker: King..
sp.l: I know well my son,
But at this time I will have it thus:
Therefore come away.

body.stage: Enters Henry the fifth, with his Lords.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come my Lords of England,
No doubt this good luck of winning this Town,
Is a sign of an honourable victory to come.
But good my Lord, go and speak to the Captains
With all speed, to number the host of the French men,
And by that means we may the better know
How to appoint the battle.

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
There are many of your men sick and diseased,
And many of them die for want of victuals.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: And why did you not tell me of it before?
If we cannot have it for money,
We will have it by dint of sword,
The law of Arms allow no less.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: I beseech your grace, to grant me a boon.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: What is that my good Lord?

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: That your grace would give me the
Euantgard in the battle.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Trust me my Lord of Oxford, I cannot:
For I have already given it to my uncle the Duke of York,
Yet I thank you for your good will.
How now, what is that?

sp.speaker: Yorke.
sp.l: I think it be some Herald of Arms.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: King of England, my Lord high Constable,
And others of the Noble men of France,
Sends me to defy thee, as open enemy to God,
Our Country, and us, and hereupon,
They presently bid thee battle.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Herald tell them, that I defy them,
As open enemies to God, my Country, and me,
And as wrongful usurpers of my right:
And whereas thou sayst they presently bid me battle,
Tell them that I think they know how to please me:
But I pray thee what place hath my lord Prince Dolphin
Here in battle.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: If it please your grace,
My Lord and King his father,
Will not let him come into the field.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why then he doth me great injury,
I thought that he and I should have played at tennis together,
Therefore I have brought tennis balls for him,
But other manner of ones than he sent me.
And Herald, tell my Lord Prince Dolphin,
That I have inured my hands with other kind of weapons
Than tennis balls, ere this time of day,
And that he shall find it ere it be long,
And so adieu my friend:
And tell my Lord, that I am ready when he will.
Come my Lords, I care not if I go to our Captains,
And I will see the number of the French army myself.
Strike up the Drum.

sp.speaker: I. Soul.
sp.l: Come away Jack Drummer, come away all,
And me will tell you what me will do,
Me will try one chance on the dice,
Who shall have the king of England and his lords.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: Come away Jack Drummer,
And try your chance, and lay down your Drum.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: O the brave apparel that the English man's
Hay broth over, I will tell you what
Me have done, me have provided a hundredth trunks,
And all to put the fine apparel of the English man's in.

sp.speaker: I. Soul.
sp.l: What do thou mean by trunkes?

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: A chest man, a hundred chests.

sp.speaker: I. Soul.
sp.l: Awee, awee, awee, Me will tell you what,
Me have put five children out of my house,
And all too little to put the fine apparel of the
English man's in.

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: O the brave, the brave apparel that we shall
Have anon, but come, and you shall see what me will try
At the kings Drummer and Fife,
Ha, me have no good luck, try you.

sp.speaker: 3. Sol.
sp.l: Faith me will try at the Earl of Northumberland
And my Lord of Willowby, with his great horse,
Snorting, farting, o brave horse.

sp.speaker: I Sol.
sp.l: Ha, byrlady you have reasonable good luck,
Now I will try at the king himself,
Ha, me have no good lucks.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: How now what make you here,
So far from the Camp?

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: Shall me tell our captain what we have done here?

sp.speaker: Drum.
sp.l: Awee, awee.

sp.speaker: 2. Sol.
sp.l: I will tell you what we have done,
We have been trying our chance on the Dice,
But none can win the king.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I think so, why he is left behind for me,
And I have set three or four chair makers awork,
To make a new disguised chair to set that womanly
King of England in, that all the people may laugh
And scoff at him.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.l: O brave Captain.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.l: I am glad, and yet with a kind of pity
To see the poor king:
Why who ever saw a more flourishing army in France
In one day, than here is? Are not here all the Peers of
France? Are not here the Normans with their fiery hand-guns,
and slaunching curtal-axes?
Are not here the Barbarians with their bard horses,
And launching spears?
Are not here Pickardes with their Crossbows and piercing
Darts.
The Henues with their cutting Glaives and sharpe
Carbuckles.
Are not here the Lance knights of Burgondie?
And on the other side, a site of poor English scabs?
Why take an English man out of his warm bed
And his stale drink, but one month,
And alas what will become of him?
But give the Frenchman a Reddish root,
And he will live with it all the days of his life.

sp.speaker: 2. Soul.
sp.p: O the brave apparel that we shall have of the English man's.

body.stage: Enters the king of England and his Lords.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come my Lords and fellows of arms,
What company is there of the French men?

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
Our Captains have numbered them,
And so near as they can judge,
They are about threescore thousand horsemen,
And forty thousand footmen.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: They threescore thousand,
And we but two thousand.
They threescore thousand footmen,
And we twelve thousand.
They are a hundred thousand,
And we forty thousand, ten to one:
My Lords and loving Country men,
Though we be few and they many,
Fear not, your quarrel is good, and God will defend you:
Pluck up your hearts, for this day we shall either have
A valiant victory, or a honourable death.
Now my Lords, I will that my uncle the Duke of Yorke,
Have the auantgard in the battle.
The Earl of Darby, the Earl of Oxford,
The Earl of Kent, the Earl of Nottingham,
The Earl of Huntington, I will have beside the army,
That they may come fresh upon them.
And I myself with the Duke of Bedford,
The Duke of Clarence and the Duke of Gloster,
Will be in the midst of the battle.
Furthermore, I will that my Lord of Willowby,
And the Earl of Northumberland,
With their troupes of horsemen, be continually running like
Wings on both sides of the army:
My Lord of Northumberland, on the left wing.
Then I will, that every archer provide him a stake of
A tree, and sharpe it at both ends,
And at the first encounter of the horsemen,
To pitch their stakes down into the ground before them,
That they may gore themselves upon them,
And then to recoil back, and shoot wholly altogether,
And so discomfit them.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
I will take that in charge, if your grace be therewith content.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: With all my heart, my good Lord of Oxford:
And go and provide quickly.

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: I thank your highness.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well my Lords, our battles are ordained,
And the French making of bonfires, and at their banquets,
But let them look, for I mean to set upon them.
Soft, here is comes some other French message.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: King of England, my Lord high Constable,
And other of my Lords, considering the poor estate of thee
And thy poor Country men,
Sends me to know what thou wilt give for thy ransom?
Perhaps thou mayst agree better cheap now,
Than when thou art conquered.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why then belike your high Constable,
Sends to know what I will give for my ransom?
Now trust me Herald, not so much as a tun of tennis balls
No not so much as one poor tennis ball,
Rather shall my body lie dead in the field, to feed crows,
Than ever England shall pay one penny ransom
For my body.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: A kingly resolution.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: No Herald, it is a kingly resolution,
And the resolution of a king:
Here take this for thy pains.
But stay my Lords, what time is it?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Prime my Lord.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Then is it good time no doubt,
For all England prayeth for us:
What my Lords, methinks you look cheerfully upon me?
Why then with one voice and like true English hearts,
With me throw up your caps, and for England,
Cry Saint George, and God and Saint. George help us.
Strike Drummer.
Saint. Dennis, Saint Dennis,
Mount Joy Saint Dennis.

body.stage: Enter King of England, and his Lords.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come my Lords come, by this time our
Swords are almost drunk with French blood,
But my Lords, which of you can tell me how many of our
Army be slain in the battle?

sp.speaker: Oxf.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
There are of the French army slain,
Above ten thousand, twenty six hundred,
Whereof are Princes and Nobles bearing banners:
Besides, all the Nobility of France are taken prisoners.
Of your Majesties Army, are slain none but the good
Duke of Yorke, and not above five or six and twenty
Common soldiers.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: For the good Duke of Yorke my uncle,
I am heartily sorry, and greatly lament his misfortune,
Yet the honourable victory which the Lord hath given us,
Doth make me much rejoice. But stay,
Here comes another French message.
Sound Trumpet.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: God save the life of the most mighty Conqueror,
The honourable king of England.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now Herald, methinks the world is changed
With you now, what I am sure it is a great disgrace for a
Herald to kneel to the king of England,
What is thy message?

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: My Lord and master, the conquered king of France,
Sends thee long health, with hearty greeting.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Herald, his greetings are welcome,
But I thank God for my health:
Well Herald, say on.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: He hath sent me to desire your Majesty,
To give him leave to go into the field to view his poor
Country men, that they may all be honourably buried.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why Herald, doth thy Lord and master
Send to me to bury the dead?
Let him bury them in Gods name.
But I pray thee Herald, where is my Lord hie Constable,
And those that would have had my ransom?

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: If it please your majesty,
He was slain in the battle.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why you may see, you will make yourselves
Sure before the victory be won, but Herald,
What Castle is this so near adjoining to our Camp?

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
It is called the Castle of Agincourt.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well then my lords of England,
For the more honour of our English men,
I will that this be forever called the battle of Agincourt.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
I have a further message to deliver to your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: What is that Herald? say on.

sp.speaker: Her.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty, my Lord and master,
Craves to parley with your Majesty.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: With a good will, so some of my Nobles
View the place for fear of treachery and treason.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: Your grace needs not to doubt that.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well, tell him then, I will come.
Now my lords, I will go into the field myself,
To view my Country men, and to have them honourably
Buried, for the French King shall never surpass me in
Courtesy, whiles I am Harry King of England.
Come on my lords.

body.stage: Enters Iohn Cobler, and Robbin Pewterer.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Now, Iohn Cobbler,
Didst thou see how the King did behave himself?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: But Robin, didst thou see what a policy
The King had, to see how the French men were killed
With the stakes of the trees.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Aye Iohn, there was a brave policy.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: What are you my masters?

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Why we be English men.

sp.speaker: Soul.
sp.l: Are you English men, then change your language
For the Kings Tents are set afire,
And all they that speak English will be killed.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: What shall we do Robin? faith I will shift,
For I can speak broken French.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Faith so can I, let us hear how thou canst speak?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Commodeuales Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: That is well, come let us be gone.
Drum and Trumpet sounds.

body.stage: Enters Dericke roming. After him a Frenchman, and takes him prisoner.

sp.speaker: Dericke.
sp.l: O good Monsieur.

sp.speaker: French man.
sp.l: Come, come, you villeaco.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O I will sir, I will.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.l: Come quickly you peasant.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: I will sir, what shall I give you?

sp.speaker: French.
sp.l: Marry thou shalt give me,
One, to, three, four, hundred Crowns.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Nay sir, I will give you more,
I will give you as many crowns as will lie on your sword.

sp.speaker: French.
sp.l: Wilt thou give me as many crowns
As will lie on my sword?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Aye marry will I, Aye but you must lay down your
Sword, or else they will not lie on your sword.

body.stage: Here the Frenchman laies downe his sword, and the clowne takes it vp, and hurles him downe.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Thou villain, darest thou look up?

sp.speaker: French.
sp.l: O good Monsieur comparteue.
Monsieur pardon me.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O you villain, now you lie at my mercy,
Dost thou remember since thou lamest me in thy short el?
O villain, now I will strike off thy head.

body.stage: Here whiles he turnes his backe, the French man runnes his wayes.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: What is he gone, mass I am glad of it,
For if he had staid, I was afraid he would have stirred again,
And then I should have been spilt,
But I will away, to kill more Frenchmen.

body.stage: Enters King of France, King of England, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now my good brother of France,
My coming into this land was not to shed blood,
But for the right of my Country, which if you can deny,
I am content peaceably to leave my siege,
And to depart out of your land.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: What is it you demand,
My loving brother of England?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: My Secretary hath it written, read it.

sp.speaker: Secretary.
sp.l: Item, that immediately Henry of England
Be crowned King of France.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: A very hard sentence,
My good brother of England.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: No more but right, my good brother of France.

sp.speaker: French King.
sp.l: Well read on.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Item, that after the death of the said Henry,
The Crown remain to him and his heirs forever.

sp.speaker: French King.
sp.l: Why then you do not only mean to
Dispossess me, but also my son.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Why my good brother of France,
You have had it long enough:
And as for Prince Dolphin,
It skills not though he sit beside the saddle:
Thus I have set it down, and thus it shall be.

sp.speaker: French King.
sp.l: You are very peremptory,
My good brother of England.

sp.speaker: Hen.
sp.l: And you as perverse, my good brother of France.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Why then belike, all that I have here is yours.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Aye even as far as the kingdom of France reaches

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Aye for by this hot beginning,
We shall scarce bring it to a calm ending.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: It is as you please, here is my resolution.

sp.speaker: Charles.
sp.l: Well my brother of England,
If you will give me a copy,
We will meet you again tomorrow.

body.stage: Exit King of France, and all their attendants.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: With a good will my good brother of France.
Secretary deliver him a copy.
My lords of England go before,
And I will follow you.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Ah Harry, thrice unhappy Harry.
Hast thou now conquered the French King,
And begins a fresh supply with his daughter,
But with what face canst thou seek to gain her love,
Which hath sought to win her fathers Crown?
Her fathers Crown said I, no it is mine own:
Aye but I love her, and must crave her,
Nay I love her and will have her.
sp.stage: Enters Lady Katheren and her Ladies.
sp.l: But here she comes:
How now fair Lady, Katheren of France,
What news?

sp.speaker: Kathren.
sp.l: If it please your Majesty,
My father sent me to know if you will debate any of these
Unreasonable demands which you require:

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now trust me Kate,
I commend thy fathers wit greatly in this,
For none in the world could sooner have made me debate it
If it were possible:
But tell me sweet Kate, canst thou tell how to love?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I cannot hate my good Lord,
Therefore far unfit were it for me to love.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Tush Kate, but tell me in plain terms,
Canst thou love the King of England?
I cannot do as these Countries do,
That spend half their time in wooing:
Tush wench, I am none such,
But wilt thou go over to England?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I would to God, that I had your Majesty,
As fast in love, as you have my father in wars,
I would not vouchsafe so much as one look,
Until you had related all these unreasonable demands.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Tush Kate, I know thou wouldst not use me so
Hardly: But tell me, canst thou love the king of England?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: How should I love him, that hath dealt so hardly
With my father.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But I will deal as easily with thee,
As thy heart can imagine, or tongue can require,
How sayst thou, what will it be?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: If I were of my own direction,
I could give you answer:
But seeing I stand at my fathers direction,
I must first know his will.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: But shall I have thy good will in the mean season?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: Whereas I can put your grace in no assurance,
I would be loath to put you in any despair.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now before God, it is a sweet wench.

body.stage: She goes aside, and speakes as followeth.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: I may think myself the happiest in the world,
That is beloved of the mighty King of England.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well Kate, are you at host with me?
Sweet Kate, tell thy father from me,
That none in the world could sooner have persuaded me to
It than thou, and so tell thy father from me.

sp.speaker: Kat.
sp.l: God keep your Majesty in good health.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Farewell sweet Kate, i'faith, it is a sweet wench,
But if I knew I could not have her fathers good will,
I would so rouse the Towers over his ears,
That I would make him be glad to bring her me,
Upon his hands and knees.

body.stage: Enters Dericke, with his girdle full of shooes.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: How now? 'Swounds it did me good to see how
I did triumph over the French men.

body.stage: Enters Iohn Cobler rouing, with a packe full of apparell.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Whoop Dericke, how dost thou?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: What Iohn, Comedeuales, alive yet.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I promise thee Dericke, I scaped hardly,
For I was within half a mile when one was killed.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Were you so?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye trust me, I had like been slain.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: But once killed, why it it is nothing,
I was four or five times slain.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Four or five times slain.
Why how couldst thou have been alive now?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: O Iohn, never say so,
For I was called the bloody soldier amongst them all.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why what didst thou?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why I will tell thee Iohn,
Every day when I went into the field,
I would take a straw and thrust it into my nose,
And make my nose bleed, and then I would go into the field,
And when the Captain saw me, he would say,
Peace a bloody soldier, and bid me stand aside,
Whereof I was glad:
But mark the chance Iohn.
I went and stood behind a tree, but mark then Iohn.
I thought I had been safe, but on a sudden,
There steps to me a lusty tall French man,
Now he drew, and I drew,
Now I lay here, and he lay there,
Now I set this leg before, and turned this backward,
And skipped quite over a hedge,
And he saw me no more there that day,
And was not this well done Iohn?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Mass Dericke, thou hast a witty head.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Aye Iohn, thou mayst see, if thou hadst take my counsel,
But what hast thou there?
I think thou hast been robbing the French men.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: I'faith Dericke, I have gotten some reparel
To carry home to my wife.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: And I have got some shoes,
For I will tell thee what I did, when they were dead,
I would go take off all their shoes.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye but Dericke, how shall we get home?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Nay 'Swounds, if they take thee,
They will hang thee,
O Iohn, never do so, if it be thy fortune to be hanged,
Be hanged in thy own language whatsoever thou dost.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why Dericke the wars is done,
We may go home now.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Aye but you may not go before you ask the king leave,
But I know a way to go home, and ask the king no leave.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: How is that Dericke?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why Iohn, thou knowest the Duke of Yorkes
Funeral must be carried into England, dost thou not?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye that I do.

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why then thou knowest we will go with it.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Aye but Dericke, how shall we do for to meet them?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: 'Swounds if I make not shift to meet them, hang me.
Sirrah, thou knowest that in every Town there will
Be ringing, and there will be cakes and drink,
Now I will go to the Clarke and Sexton
And keep a-talking, and say, O this fellow rings well,
And thou shalt go and take a piece of cake, then I will ring,
And thou shalt say, o this fellow keeps a good stint,
And then I will go drink to thee all the way:
But I marvel what my dame will say when we come home,
Because we have not a French word to cast at a Dog
By the way?

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Why what shall we do Dericke?

sp.speaker: Der.
sp.l: Why Iohn, I will go before and call my dame whore,
And thou shalt come after and set fire on the house,
We may do it Iohn, for I will prove it,
Because we be soldiers.

sp.speaker: Iohn.
sp.l: Dericke help me to carry my shoes and boots.

body.stage: Enters King of England, Lord of Oxford and Exeter, then the King of France, Prince Dolphin, and the Duke of Burgondie, and attendants.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Now my good brother of France,
I hope by this time you have deliberated of your answer?

sp.speaker: Fr. King..
sp.l: Aye my well-beloved brother of England,
We have viewed it over with our learned Council,
But cannot find that you should be crowned
King of France.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: What not King of France, then nothing,
I must be King: but my loving brother of France,
I can hardly forget the late injuries offered me,
When I came last to parley,
The French men had better have raked
The bowels out of their fathers carcasses,
Than to have fired my Tents,
And if I knew thy son Prince Dolphin for one,
I would so rouse him, as he was never so roused.

sp.speaker: Fr. King..
sp.l: I dare swear for my sons innocency
In this matter.
But if this please you, that immediately you be
Proclaimed and crowned heir and Regent of France,
Not King, because I myself was once crowned King.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Heir and Regent of France, that is well,
But that is not all that I must have.

sp.speaker: Fr. King..
sp.l: The rest my Secretary hath in writing.

sp.speaker: Secret.
sp.l: Item, that Henry King of England,
Be Crowned heir and Regent of France,
During the life of King Charles, and after his death,
The Crown with all rights, to remain to King Henry
Of England, and to his heirs forever.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well my good brother of France,
There is one thing I must needs desire.

sp.speaker: Fr. King..
sp.l: What is that my good brother of England?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: That all your Nobles must be sworn to be true to me.

sp.speaker: Fr. King.
sp.l: Whereas they have not stuck with greater
Matters, I know they will not stick with such a trifle,
Begin you my Lord Duke of Burgondie.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come my Lord of Burgondie,
Take your oath upon my sword.

sp.speaker: Burgon.
sp.l: I Philip Duke of Burgondie,
Swear to Henry King of England,
To be true to him, and to become his league-man,
And that if I Philip, hear of any foreign power
Coming to invade the said Henry or his heirs,
Then I the said Philip to send him word,
And aide him with all the power I can make,
And thereunto I take my oath.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Come Prince Dolphin, you must swear too.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Well my brother of France,
There is one thing more I must needs require of you.

sp.speaker: Fr. King..
sp.l: Wherein is it that we may satisfy your Majesty?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: A trifle my good brother of France.
I mean to make your daughter Queen of England,
If she be willing, and you therewith content:
How sayst thou Kate, canst thou love the King of England?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: How should I love thee, which is my fathers enemy?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Tut stand not upon these points,
It is you must make us friends:
I know Kate, thou art not a little proud, that I love thee:
What wench, the King of England?

sp.speaker: French King.
sp.l: Daughter let nothing stand betwixt the
King of England and thee, agree to it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.l: I had best whilst he is willing,
Lest when I would, he will not:
I rest at your Majesties command.

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: Welcome sweet Kate, but my brother of France,
What say you to it?

sp.speaker: French King.
sp.l: With all my heart I like it,
But when shall be your wedding day?

sp.speaker: Hen. 5.
sp.l: The first Sunday of the next month,
God willing.
Sound Trumpets.
